hedline.hl1: Taiwan Aides Voice Hope on China Ties

abstract.p: Two of Taiwan's top security officials express cautious hope that relations with mainland may improve following Pres Chen Shui-bian's inaugural speech and nonbelligerent reply from Beijing (S)

block.p: Two of Taiwan's top security officials expressed cautious hope today that relations with the mainland could improve after President Chen Shui-bian's inaugural speech and a nonbelligerent reply from Beijing.

In Beijing, officials stressed that China would be pragmatic in dealings with Taiwan. Mr. Chen promised at his inauguration not to declare independence and made soothing comments about a shared history and culture. He also referred cryptically to the ''question of a possible future 'one China.' ''

Two of Taiwan's top security officials expressed cautious hope today that relations with the mainland could improve after President Chen Shui-bian's inaugural speech and a nonbelligerent reply from Beijing.

In Beijing, officials stressed that China would be pragmatic in dealings with Taiwan. Mr. Chen promised at his inauguration not to declare independence and made soothing comments about a shared history and culture. He also referred cryptically to the ''question of a possible future 'one China.' ''

Beijing replied equally vaguely that frozen talks might resume if the two sides could ''express in their own way orally'' their support for the ''one China'' principle. More tangibly, both sides seem intent on allowing direct commerce across the Taiwan Strait.

''We're not disappointed'' by Beijing's response was how Tsai Ing-wen, new head of Taipei's Mainland Affairs Council, put it. ''My own reading,'' she said, ''is that they have softened their position somewhat to try and find ways to move forward.''
Chiou I-jen, deputy chief of Taiwan's National Security Council, said, ''At least the situation has calmed down.''
